verses.text: Everyone who believes that Jesus is the Christ has been born of God, and everyone who loves the Father also loves the one born of Him.
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus as the Messiah is the basis for being born of God. This connection between the Father and the Son emphasizes the inseparability of the two and points to the shared life within the family of believers. The wording 'born of God' echoes John 3:3-8, highlighting spiritual rebirth through faith and grace.

verses.text: By this we know that we love the children of God: when we love God and obey His commandments.
verses.comment: True love for fellow believers is proven by love for God and obedience to His commands — love and moral duty are deeply intertwined, supporting the concept of a faith that is lived out, not just professed.

verses.text: For this is the love of God: that we keep His commandments. And His commandments are not burdensome.
verses.comment: Loving God is demonstrated through obedience. God’s commands are not given to weigh us down but to give life. The spiritual life is sustained by grace, making the law a delight rather than a burden.

verses.text: For everyone who has been born of God overcomes the world. And this is the victory that has overcome the world—our faith.
verses.comment: Spiritual rebirth gives the power to overcome the sin and temptations of the world. Faith is shown here as victorious—a gift leading to triumph over all obstacles.

verses.text: Who is it that overcomes the world except the one who believes that Jesus is the Son of God?
verses.comment: Belief in Jesus’ divine sonship is the mark of genuine victory. The confession of Jesus as Son of God is essential (see also Matthew 16:16), and is the foundation of true faith and spiritual triumph.

verses.text: This is He who came by water and blood—Jesus Christ; not by water only, but by water and blood. And the Spirit is the one who testifies, because the Spirit is truth.
verses.comment: ‘Water and blood’ points to Jesus’ baptism and crucifixion, affirming both His incarnation and atoning death. The Spirit’s testimony shows the threefold witness to Christ’s divine mission. There’s a strong emphasis on the physical reality of Christ’s humanity and the necessity of sacraments (cf. John 3:5 for water, and John 6:53 for blood).

verses.text: For there are three that testify:
verses.comment: In keeping with the Old Testament requirement for multiple witnesses, this verse emphasizes the certainty of the testimony concerning Jesus. (Note: early manuscripts do not contain the explicit mention of the Trinity found in some later translations.)

verses.text: the Spirit and the water and the blood; and these three agree as one.
verses.comment: Spirit, water, and blood harmoniously testify to Christ’s person and mission. This harmony points towards the visible and invisible means by which God’s grace is conveyed. Sacramental overtones are present here, particularly in relation to baptism and the Lord’s Supper.

verses.text: If we receive the testimony of men, the testimony of God is greater, for this is the testimony of God that He has borne concerning His Son.
verses.comment: God’s own testimony—at Christ’s baptism, transfiguration, and resurrection—is far superior to human witness (see Mark 1:11, Luke 9:35). It underlines the authority of divine revelation in confirming Jesus’ identity.

verses.text: The one who believes in the Son of God has the testimony in himself. The one who does not believe God has made Him a liar, because he has not believed in the testimony that God has given concerning His Son.
verses.comment: Faith brings internal assurance—a subjective witness formed by the Spirit. Rejecting this is seen as calling God a liar, meaning unbelief is a moral, not merely intellectual, issue.

verses.text: And this is the testimony: that God has given us eternal life, and this life is in His Son.
verses.comment: Eternal life is presented as a gift given now, not just future hope, and is found only through union with Jesus Christ (see John 10:28; John 17:3).

verses.text: Whoever has the Son has life; whoever does not have the Son of God does not have life.
verses.comment: Union with Christ is necessary for spiritual life. This exclusivity highlights the necessity of an ongoing, living relationship with Jesus—hinting at the importance of abiding in Him (John 15:4-7).

verses.text: I write these things to you who believe in the name of the Son of God, so that you may know that you have eternal life.
verses.comment: John’s purpose is to give certainty—not just hope—of eternal life to believers. Assurance of salvation is rooted not in self-confidence but in trust in Christ.

verses.text: And this is the confidence that we have toward Him: that if we ask anything according to His will, He hears us.
verses.comment: Prayer is powerful when aligned with God’s will. True Christian prayer seeks communion with God’s desires rather than imposing our own.

verses.text: And if we know that He hears us in whatever we ask, we know that we have the requests that we have asked of Him.
verses.comment: Confidence in prayer rests on trust in God’s goodness. This verse encourages bold, persistent, and faith-filled prayer, consistent with the teaching of Jesus on prayer’s efficacy.

verses.text: If anyone sees his brother committing a sin not leading to death, he shall ask, and God will give him life—to those who commit sins not leading to death. There is sin that leads to death; I do not say that one should pray for that.
verses.comment: This verse distinguishes between sins that do not lead to death (venial) and those that do (mortal). The Church historically teaches a distinction between degrees of sin, showing that not all transgressions have the same effect on one’s relationship with God. Intercessory prayer for others shows the communal nature of Christian life.

verses.text: All wrongdoing is sin, but there is sin that does not lead to death.
verses.comment: Not every sin cuts off spiritual life completely. This reaffirms the previous point: grave sin (mortal) differs from lesser sins in its effect and requires restoration with God, echoing the idea of sacramental confession.

verses.text: We know that anyone born of God does not keep on sinning, but the one who is born of God keeps him safe, and the evil one does not touch him.
verses.comment: Being born of God transforms a person’s life. There is divine protection from evil, but the language allows for continued moral effort and cooperation with God’s grace.

verses.text: We know that we are from God, and the whole world lies under the power of the evil one.
verses.comment: There is a sharp distinction between those in Christ and the fallen world, which remains in the grip of the evil one. This signals the need for discernment, prayer, and the ongoing ministry of the Church to keep believers safe.

verses.text: And we know that the Son of God has come and has given us understanding, so that we may know Him who is true; and we are in Him who is true, in His Son Jesus Christ. He is the true God and eternal life.
verses.comment: This verse makes a powerful declaration of the divinity of Jesus: 'He is the true God and eternal life.' By grace, we have a real share in God’s divine life. This verse underlies the doctrine of the real presence and transformative union with Christ at the center of authentic Christian faith.

verses.text: Little children, keep yourselves from idols.
verses.comment: The epistle closes with an exhortation to remain faithful and to avoid idolatry—anything that would rival God’s exclusive claim on the believer’s heart. In the early Church, idolatry could refer to both external images and internal attachments, reminding the faithful to keep true worship and full devotion.
